 Science is a system used to narrow down answers to questions about the universe. It is pretty much the opposite of faith. However, most people today don't really understand what it means to do science. Real science is counter-intutive for humans, and it takes great effort and care to do ti properly.
 
 Scientists often stay off track, that is why other scientists are so critical of each others work. It is an attempt to keep everyone focused.
 
 Science based method: narrow down possible answers with complete confidence. The best working theory is only "correct" to a certain resolution or threshold, past which predictions should not be made. This means that you can never really know the "perfect" truth with science, but you can get PRETTY DAM CLOSE. Advances are made by disproving competing ideas to narrow down the possibilities.
 
 Most of our "theories" are really only generalizations that work under specific conditions.
 
 Here is the best example: Newtons theory of Gravity. Works fantastic for everyday objects. Good enough to launch objects into orbit, predict motion of plants, moon etc.
 
 But, at a certain point you have to admit that is it really just an approximation. It was right, but only up to a point, beyond which you have to use General Relativity to make accurate predictions.
 
 But, General Relativity has its own limit of use... beyond which we have to use something else... something that we currently don't know about...
 
 So, think about the scientific approach to truth like ripping a piece of paper. You start with a blank sheet open to all possibilities, but through careful testing you can narrow the answer down to a small area of the sheet, by ripping away the false parts (disproving competing ideas). Eventually you have a tiny scrap that you know contains the truth, but you really don't have the exact truth since the sheet still has a small finite size. You may continue to rip away pieces by disproving the false parts forever... you may never actually have the perfect truth just like 0.9999999~ is never really = 1, but it is close enough to generalize it to 1. That tiny scrap always has a threshold (size) beyond which is a small unknown area.
 
 So, no technically you can never find perfect truth with science, but you can narrow it down to whatever threshold you want given enough work and time.
 
 You want a black and white answer, unfortunately, the universe is not black and white.

Ok here's another question.
 
 Here's a quote from Wikipedia: Scientific method 
 
Scientific methods or processes are considered fundamental to the scientific investigation and acquisition of new knowledge based upon physical evidence by scientific communities. Scientists use observations and reasoning to develop technologies and propose explanations for natural phenomena in the form of hypotheses. Predictions from these hypotheses are tested by experiment and further technologies developed. Any hypothesis which is cogent enough to make predictions can then be tested reproducibly in this way. Once it has been established that a hypothesis is sound (by use of the above methods), it becomes a theory. Sometimes scientific development takes place differently with a theory first being developed gaining support on the basis of its logic and principles.

 Generally we believe that science should be consistent with logical principles.

Science refers to either:
